lines.text: [first lines]
I'm Bobby Jay Jones.
Shut the door and take off you hat.
[about to be released from prison, Clay empties his pistol's bullets into the warden's trash can]
I wish you had kept them. I was countin' on you gettin' in a fix and comin' right back here.
I ain't gettin' in any trouble... until I find the trouble I want.
They let you out or you bust out?
Ain't nobody busts out of Canon City.
Sure doesn't seem like seven years.
It does to me. I done 'em.
Say I told you where you could find Sam. What would you do?
Pay you and kill him.
Hey, Gramps! Full quart of bourbon - new bottle.
I don't knows you're old enough.
Oh, ho-ho-ho. Well, we're old enough and you're too old, Gramps.
You want glasses or just put a nipple on the bottle?
People oughta be like dogs - you get too old, just shoot 'em.
But who's to say who gets shot?
Why me, honey.
Sooner of later, it comes your turn, 'cause if you live you get older and if you live long enough you get old.
Not much of a horse.
Best I could get for not much cash.
Hey, you told me you could cook!
You point a gun and I'll tell you I could fly and do walkin' on water and turnin' sticks into snakes.
Seems like I seen that pony before.
Could be. I got him out of your corral back there. You want to get rid of him?
If I did, I would have left the gate open.
A little scrub like him, I figure he might be worth a couple of dollars.
He's got a sentimental value - belonged to my late wife.
Well, why don't you put a sentimental price on him?
You're a generous woman.
Selfish - this is female practicality. You leave her here, you'll have to come back.
I might keep on movin'.
I'll take that gamble.
[last lines]
I see you finally got a new hat. That's not a Texas hat, either.
Oh? What about it?
Oh, nothing. Are you my father?
You asked me that before. Are you going to start that again?
Not if you don't want me to. But why did you come back?
Damned if I know.

Your friends! They took turns gunning old Trooper in his wheelchair. Shot him in the belly so he died real slow. Do you know what happens when you're shot in the belly? Well, you can't move. You can't breathe. You feel yourself fillin' up with blood... with pain! And you can't die!
[discussing Sam Foley, the partner who shot Clay in the back]
But hell, I always liked that fella.
So did I... until I stopped.
[Clay sniffs the ground outside his friends burned down ranchhouse]
Is it injuns?
Worse. Worse than injuns, Decky. That there is the smell of hard times.
